title: Jagr scores twice to lead Panthers to 3-2 victory over Sabres | Hockey
text:
SUNRISE, Fla. -- Jaromir Jagr was 24 years old and into his sixth NHL season with the Penguins when Sabres highly touted rookie Jack Eichel was born.
While Eichel -- the second overall pick of last June's NHL Entry Draft in the BB&T Center -- showed flashes of his potential, it was the seemingly ageless 43-year-old wonder schooling the teenager and Sabres with two goals in a strangely interrupted first period, as well as an assist in a 3-2 victory Thursday night.
The Panthers, 4-0-1 against the 30th-ranked Sabres last season, are 8-0-1 against them over their last nine games and have notched at least a point in their last 16 meetings (12-1-3). The Panthers have allowed just one goal in each of their four games.
It helps that goalie Roberto Luongo's eyes practically bulge out of his mask when he sees those clashing swords coming at him as he made 24 saves to improve to 15-6-2 with a sub-2.00 goals-against-average against the Sabres. He has won seven straight against Buffalo, including four shutouts. Luongo's 403rd victory ties him with Grant Fuhr for ninth on the all-time wins list.
All preseason the Panthers emphasized how critical it was to get off to a fast start this season after falling short of the playoffs last year. Thanks to the schedule-makers as well as a blossoming young team on the upswing they improved to 3-1 to match their best start since the 2011-12 season which also happens to be the last time they made the playoffs.
Also off to a sensational start is Jagr, who has four goals in the first four games, including two multiple-goal outings (124 career). Jagr didn't score his fourth goal last season with the Devils until Nov. 28 in his 23rd game.
The Panthers, who scored on their first two power-play chances in the season opener, had converted just 1 of 14 since and none over their last two games. That dubious streak ended at 8:42 of the first period when Aleksander Barkov -- who's evolving into an elite playmaker in his third season -- set up Jagr in front of the right circle for a snapper past goalie Chad Johnson.
Johnson, the Sabres' 10th goalie in net since last February, has replaced injured starter Robin Lehner. Jagr's 205th power-play goal tied him with Joe Sakic for 13th place all-time. It was Jagr's first goal against the Sabres since Dec. 7, 2011.
In a bizarre (near) end to the first period, a couple of players crashed into the boards and dislodged a portion of the glass in the Panthers' zone. Instead of waiting for the maintenance crew to repair the glass, the on-ice officials resorted to Rule 17:07 and signaled for an early intermission with 2:53 left on the clock.
When the players came out of the dressing room they remained on the same side of the ice, and just 27 seconds into the continuation of the first period, Jagr strolled in before smoking a riser past Johnson. It was Jagr's 44th goal against the 1-3 Sabres and 100th point in his 84th game against them.
When the 2:53 elapsed the players switched sides, but the Panthers now led 2-0 after one. From there the Panthers seem to doze off, but despite three consecutive power plays they wouldn't score until they were at even strength at 7:10 when rookie defenseman Jake McCabe crashed the net to bury Nick Foligno's pass. It was McCabe's first NHL goal in his 11th game.
Leading 2-1 after two, Jagr set up the insurance goal on another power-play goal as his blast off Johnson's pads went to Barkov for the rebound at 4:24 of the third.
The Panthers special teams were dominating after killing off Buffalo's first five power-play goals but finally Tyler Ennis' slapper from the point made it 3-2 at 12:35 to create a nervous ending.
